question.text: For extrinsic semiconductors; when doping level is increased;

options.text: Fermi-level of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>p</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>- type semiconductors will not be affected.

Fermi-level of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>p</mi></math>-type semiconductor will go upward and Fermi-level of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>-type semiconductors will go downward.

Fermi-level of both p-type and n-type semiconductors will go upward for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mi>F</mi></msub><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math> and downward for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mi>F</mi></msub><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo>,</mo></math> where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>T</mi><mi>F</mi></msub></math> is Fermi temperature.

Fermi-level of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>p</mi></math>- type semiconductors will go downward and Fermi-level of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>- type semiconductor will go upward.

solution.text:
In n-type semiconductor pentavalent impurity is added. Each pentavalent impurity donates a free electron. So the Fermi-level of n -type semiconductor will go upward.
& In p-type semiconductor trivalent impurity is added. Each trivalent impurity creates a hole in the valence band. So the Fermi-level of p-type semiconductor will go downward.
